My dear wife of my heart Porto Alegre, December 15, 1835.

I have already received two of yours, and from the joy both have produced in me, you can judge by the sensations you feel when you receive mine. I had been quite distressed until a few days ago thinking that well-directed intrigues had produced distrust between ours; however, seeing on the contrary that firm progress is being made for the good of our Province, pleasure has reborn in my heart. I now live content, and the young ladies do not leave me troubled; poor things, they waste their time, because I do not care for them and, consequently, all say that there is no girl more fortunate than you, that I am the example of the married, and with this I make the marital state desirable. And how about that? See how much my behavior is worth and how happy you are having a young, handsome, well-made, and faithful husband. Where else is so much found together? Indeed, in this century it is a phenomenon, a marvel, etc., etc.

Hugs to our children, regards to all our people, and goodbye until the 23rd of this month, God willing; save me something. Your husband of the heart Almeida.

Madam Bernardina Barcelos de Almeida. Pelotas.
